title: 115_s1898
content: The "Repeal and Refund Act" is cited as the short title. It repeals the individual mandate. The "Repeal and Refund Act" eliminates the requirement to maintain minimum essential coverage under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The curr_chunk outlines various healthcare programs including Medicare, Medicaid, CHIP, TRICARE, and programs under title 38 for veterans. The curr_chunk discusses different types of health plans including employer-sponsored plans, plans in the individual market, and grandfathered health plans. The curr_chunk defines a grandfathered health plan and an eligible employer-sponsored plan, which includes group health plans offered by employers and other plans in the small or large group market within a State. The curr_chunk explains that minimum essential coverage does not include certain health insurance benefits, such as excepted benefits described in specific sections of the Public Health Service Act. Individuals residing outside the United States or in territories are considered to have minimum essential coverage. The curr_chunk clarifies that individuals can be treated as having minimum essential coverage under certain circumstances, such as residing in specific territories or during certain periods as described in the section. It also aligns insurance-related terms with the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The curr_chunk specifies eligibility criteria for coverage months under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, amending certain clauses in the tax code related to minimum essential coverage. The curr_chunk amends section 36B(c) of the tax code to define "required contribution" for individuals eligible for minimum essential coverage through an employer-sponsored plan. The curr_chunk amends section 36B(c) of the tax code to define the annual premium for the lowest cost bronze plan available in the individual market through the Exchange for individuals eligible for minimum essential coverage. The curr_chunk involves amendments to various sections of the tax code, replacing references to "section 5000A(f)" with "section 36B(g)". The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing the item related to chapter 48. Additionally, amendments are made to the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, replacing references to "section 500A(f)(2)" with "section 36B(g)(2)". Individuals eligible for enrollment in a plan year must be under the age of 30 at the beginning of the year. Amendments are made to various sections of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, including removing references to "section 500A(f)(2)" and replacing them with "section 36B(g)(2)". Amendments to the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act include changes to sections 1332(a)(2)(D) and 1401(c)(1)(A)(iii), removing references to sections 5000A and updating them to sections 36B and 4980H. Amendments to the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act involve updating references from sections 5000A to sections 36B and 4980H, including changes to section 1411 and section 1411(b)(4)(C). Amendments to the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act involve striking certain clauses and sections, such as paragraph (5) and clause (iv) in section 1411(e)(4)(B), and updating references from section 5000A to section 36B in section 2715(b)(3)(G)(i). The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2013. Additionally, part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by repealing subpart D, with conforming amendments made to section 6056(d). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for coordination with other requirements, such as providing returns or statements under section 6051. Additionally, certain clauses and sections are amended or repealed, including subsection (c) of section 1502 of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is repealed, and a taxpayer refund program is implemented for penalties paid under section 5000A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this subsection apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2013. The waiver of the statute of limitations extends the period for claiming a refund for penalties paid under section 5000A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 until the deadline for filing the tax return for the taxable year including December 31, 2017.
